thread.title: Trump Today: A Russian cloud grows over the White House
thread.title_full: Trump Today: A Russian cloud grows over the White House - The Boston Globe

title: Trump Today: A Russian cloud grows over the White House

locations.name: eli lake of the bloomberg view

text:
Google+
Saul Loeb/AFP/Getty Images
President Trump.
By Martin Finucane Globe Staff February 15, 2017
Welcome to Trump Today, a one-stop entry point for the latest news on the 45th president of the United States.
Afternoon update
Advertisement
At a news conference and photo opportunity, President Donald J. Trump did not answer questions on a bombshell report by the New York Times that members of his campaign and other associates had multiple contacts with senior Russian intelligence officials in the year before the election. He did, however, speak out in support of Michael Flynn, who was forced to resign as his national security adviser over misleading the White House about post-election calls to the Russian ambassador.
Trump asked Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to hold off on building Jewish settlements in land the Palestinians claim for their future state. He also said he wasn’t committed to a two-state solution to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. “I’m looking at two-state and one-state, and I like the one that both parties like,” he said.
Get Ground Game in your inbox: Daily updates and analysis on national politics from James Pindell. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here The chaos enveloping Trump’s White House is generating growing frustrations among Republicans in Congress as they are put on the defensive by Democrats who are redoubling demands for tough investigations of the new administration’s ties to Russia, the Globe’s Victoria McGrane and Astead W. Herndon report .
Andrew Puzder, Trump’s pick to run the Labor Department, withdrew , just a day before he was set to appear in front of a Senate committee for a confirmation hearing, Globe correspondent Tyler Pager reports.
Galvanized by Trump’s win, Massachusetts women are planning campaigns, the Globe’s Stephanie Ebbert reports.
Advertisement
Make no mistake: This is what a White House in crisis looks like, the Globe’s James Pindell writes in his Ground Game analysis.
Today’s schedule
Trump and Netanyahu were slated to hold meetings and a working lunch, as well as hold the news conference.
Trump also participated in a listening session with the Retail Industry Leaders Association and member company CEOs and was slated to speak with President Mauricio Macri of Argentina by telephone. In the evening, Trump will host Senator Marco Rubio, his former bitter rival for the Republican nomination, for dinner.
What’s he been tweeting?
Trump launched a tweetstorm at 6:40 a.m. Wednesday, first lashing out at MSNBC and CNN, then lauding a Fox News show.
The fake news media is going crazy with their conspiracy theories and blind hatred. @MSNBC & @CNN are unwatchable. @foxandfriends is great!
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 15, 2017
The Republican then charged that the “Russian connection” story was an attempt to cover up the flaws in Democrat Hillary Clinton’s campaign.
This Russian connection non-sense is merely an attempt to cover-up the many mistakes made in Hillary Clinton's losing campaign.
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 15, 2017
He criticized the New York Times and Washington Post and their use of sources and said it was — “Just like Russia.”
Information is being illegally given to the failing @nytimes & @washingtonpost by the intelligence community (NSA and FBI?).Just like Russia
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 15, 2017
He criticized the leaks further.
Thank you to Eli Lake of The Bloomberg View - "The NSA & FBI...should not interfere in our politics...and is" Very serious situation for USA
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 15, 2017
Then he referred to the Russian takeover of Crimea from the Ukraine, which happened during the Obama administration.
Crimea was TAKEN by Russia during the Obama Administration. Was Obama too soft on Russia?
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 15, 2017
Finally, he returned to criticism of news leaks, calling them “Very un-American!”
The real scandal here is that classified information is illegally given out by "intelligence" like candy. Very un-American!
— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 15, 2017
Stepping back
The Washington Post’s Dan Balz says we are witnessing the “public humbling of a new president.”
More headlines
Before national security adviser Flynn was forced to resign Monday night, Trump was aware for “weeks” that Flynn had misled Vice President Mike Pence and White House officials about his his pre-inauguration phone calls to the Russian ambassador.
A White House spokesman said Flynn was forced to resign not because of any legal issues, but because Trump had lost trust in him.
Kellyanne Conway, the high-profile Trump adviser, should be disciplined for publicly endorsing Ivanka Trump’s product line, the US government’s chief ethics watchdog found.
House Republicans blocked a Democratic attempt to use an obscure law to get President Donald Trump’s tax returns from the IRS.
President Trump’s travel ban targeting nationals of seven Muslim-majority countries may not have held up in court, but it appears quite successful at keeping tourists out of the United States, the Globe Christopher Muther reports .
Some people weren’t happy after Ivanka Trump posted a photo of herself seated at the Oval Office desk with her father and Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau flanking her.
The briefing
Clearly feeling the heat, Trump spokesman Sean Spicer gamely battled reporters at Tuesday’s briefing. Go to 15:23 on the video to see the Q and A portion of the briefing, which leads off with Spicer sidestepping a question on whether the Russians had been in contact with the Trump campaign.
Material from The Associated Press was used in this report.
